oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Broadcloth coat tailored by Governor Andrew Johnson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadcloth coat tailored by Governor Andrew Johnson in 1853.

Facing family poverty after the death of his father, the young Johnson had been apprenticed to James Selby, a tailor in Raleigh, North Carolina, where he learned the craft. In 1826, Johnson moved to Greeneville where he opened his own tailoring business. He continued practicing his skills as a tailor throughout his political career as Governor of Tennessee and President of the United States. The coat is now housed in the collections of the Tennessee State Museum, Nashville, Tennessee.
